source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk3
evidence_span: The temperature dependence of the growth constants for the ZrO₂ and for the combined layer thickness are presented in Figs. 4a and 4b. The data measured on the heated and nonheated surfaces produced two distinct curves with approximately the same slope and activation energies.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk3
evidence_span: The temperature dependence of the growth constants for the ZrO₂ and for the combined layer thickness are presented in Figs. 4a and 4b. The data measured on the heated and nonheated surfaces produced two distinct curves with approximately the same slope and activation energies.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk3
evidence_span: A discontinuity in the growth rate is observed around 1510°C This is associated with the development of the cubic high-temperature oxide phase [4].

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk3
evidence_span: No other discontinuity in growth rate was observed, neither upon melting of the underlying metal at 1980°C nor upon transformation of the duplex (tetragonal and cubic) ZrO₂ layer to a single-phase cubic oxide at 2285°C.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk3
evidence_span: No other discontinuity in growth rate was observed, neither upon melting of the underlying metal at 1980°C nor upon transformation of the duplex (tetragonal and cubic) ZrO₂ layer to a single-phase cubic oxide at 2285°C.

evidence_span: Below 1510°C the β-Zr reacts with oxygen to form a layer of tetragonal ZrO₂ and a layer of oxygen-stabilized α-Zr(O)

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk3
evidence_span: Above 1510°C a duplex oxide layer forms consisting of an outer layer of tetragonal and an inner layer of cubic zirconia

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk3
evidence_span: Depending on the oxygen content of the metal, β-Zircaloy melts at 1760 to 1940°C and α-Zr(O) at 1900 to 1975°C

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk3
evidence_span: Depending on the oxygen content of the metal, β-Zircaloy melts at 1760 to 1940°C and α-Zr(O) at 1900 to 1975°C

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk3
evidence_span: Thus above 1980°C the metal phase exists as a single molten phase and the only reaction product that forms is the duplex oxide

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk3
evidence_span: the tetragonal oxide converts to the cubic phase above 2285°C, resulting in a single cubic-oxide layer

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk3
evidence_span: The presence of the α-Zr(O) metal stringers in the oxide are a product of the eutectoid decomposition that the substoichiometric cubic oxide undergoes upon cooling through 1490°C to form α-Zr(O), about 10 vol%, and tetragonal ZrO₂

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk3
evidence_span: a second eutectoid decomposition occurs in tetragonal ZrO₂ upon cooling through 1000°C, producing stable monoclinic ZrO₂ and α-Zr(O). The latter phase is about 1 to 2 vol%

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk3
evidence_span: at 1800°C 23% of the total 400 μm oxide thickness was tetragonal ZrO₂

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk3
evidence_span: at 1800°C 23% of the total 400 μm oxide thickness was tetragonal ZrO₂

evidence_span: The melting of the Zircaloy was characterized by the presence of ZrO2 precipitates in the metal. These precipitates formed when the hypereutectic liquid was cooled below 1900°C

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk4
evidence_span: Oxidation rates for Zircaloy-4 in steam above 1500°C, as measured by our laser-heating technique, are greater than those previously reported

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk4
evidence_span: A discontinuity in the growth-rate constants of the reaction layers at 1510°C occurs as a result of the change in oxide crystal structure from tetragonal to a duplex tetragonal and cubic layer

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk4
evidence_span: No discontinuity in oxide-growth rate occurs upon melting of the metal phase (at least if it remains nonturbulent) or when the oxide becomes a single cubic phase at about 2285°C

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk4
evidence_span: Large temperature gradients across the oxide thickness alter the cubic-to-tetragonal thickness ratio above 1510°C and therefore may also affect the oxidation kinetics

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_038_chunk4
evidence_span: The presence of large amounts of hydrogen, up to at least 90 mol% hydrogen, mixed with the steam does not affect the oxidation rates so long as the steam supply to the sample surface is sufficient
